class leo.core.leoImport.RecursiveImportController(c, one_file=False, theTypes=None, safe_at_file=True, use_at_edit=False)¶

Recursively import all python files in a directory and clean the result.

clean(p, ext)¶
  • Move a shebang line from the first child to the root.
  • Move a leading docstring in the first child to the root.
  • Use a section reference for declarations.
  • Remove leading and trailing blank lines from all nodes.
  • Merge a node containing nothing but comments with the next node.
  • Merge a node containing no class or def lines with the previous node.
clean_all(p)¶

Clean all imported nodes.

clean_blank_lines(p)¶

Remove leading and trailing blank lines from all nodes.

clear_dirty_bits(p)¶
dump_headlines(p)¶
fix_back_slashes(p)¶

Convert backslash to slash in all headlines.

import_dir(root, dir_)¶

Import selected files from dir_, a directory.

merge_comment_nodes(p, delim)¶

Merge a node containing nothing but comments with the next node.

merge_extra_nodes(p)¶

Merge a node containing no class or def lines with the previous node

minimize_headlines(p, prefix)¶

Create @path nodes to minimize the paths required in descendant nodes.

move_decorator_lines(p)¶

Move trailing decorator lines to the next node.

move_doc_string(root)¶

Move a leading docstring in the first child to the root node.

move_shebang_line(root)¶

Move a shebang line from the first child to the root.

post_process(p, prefix)¶

Traverse p’s tree, replacing all nodes that start with prefix by the smallest equivalent @path or @file node.

remove_empty_nodes(p)¶
rename_decls(root)¶

Use a section reference for declarations.

run(dir_)¶

Import all the .py files in dir_.

leo.core.leoKeys module¶

Gui-independent keystroke handling for Leo.

class leo.core.leoKeys.AutoCompleterClass(k)¶

A class that inserts autocompleted and calltip text in text widgets. This class shows alternatives in the tabbed log pane.

The keyHandler class contains hooks to support these characters: invoke-autocompleter-character (default binding is ‘.’) invoke-calltips-character (default binding is ‘(‘)

abort()¶
appendTabName(word)¶
attr_matches(s, namespace)¶

Compute matches when string s is of the form name.name....name.

Evaluates s using eval(s,namespace)

Assuming the text is of the form NAME.NAME....[NAME], and is evaluatable in the namespace, it will be evaluated and its attributes (as revealed by dir()) are used as possible completions.

For class instances, class members are are also considered.)

Warning: this can still invoke arbitrary C code, if an object with a __getattr__ hook is evaluated.

autoComplete(event=None, force=False)¶

An event handler for autocompletion.

autoCompleteForce(event=None)¶

Show autocompletion, even if autocompletion is not presently enabled.

auto_completer_state_handler(event)¶

class leo.core.leoKeys.GetArg(ga, c, prompt='full-command: ', tabName='Completion')¶

A class encapsulating all k.getArg logic.

k.getArg maps to ga.get_arg, which gets arguments in the minibuffer.

For details, see the docstring for ga.get_arg

compute_tab_list(ga, tabList, backspace=False, allow_empty_completion=False)¶

Compute and show the available completions.

do_back_space(ga, tabList, completion=True)¶

Handle a backspace and update the completion list.

Handle a non-special character.

do_end(ga, event, char, stroke)¶

A return or escape has been seen.

do_state_zero(ga, completion, event, handler, oneCharacter, returnKind, returnState, tabList, useMinibuffer)¶

Do state 0 processing.

do_tab(ga, tabList, completion=True)¶

Handle tab completion when the user hits a tab.

do_tab_callback(ga)¶

If the command-name handler has a tab_callback, call handler.tab_callback() and return True.

do_tab_cycling(ga, common_prefix, tabList)¶

Put the next (or first) completion in the minibuffer.

get_arg(ga, event, returnKind=None, returnState=None, handler=None, tabList=, []completion=True, oneCharacter=False, stroke=None, useMinibuffer=True)¶

Accumulate an argument. Enter the given return state when done.

Ctrl-G will abort this processing at any time.

All commands needing user input call k.getArg, which just calls ga.get_arg.

The arguments to ga.get_arg are as follows:

event: The event passed to the command.

returnKind=None: A string. returnState=None, An int. handler=None, A function.

When the argument is complete, ga.do_end does:

if kind: k.setState(kind,n,handler)

tabList=[]: A list of possible completions.

completion=True: True if completions are enabled.

oneCharacter=False: True if k.arg should be a single character.

stroke=None: The incoming key stroke.

useMinibuffer=True: True: put focus in the minibuffer while accumulating arguments.
False allows sort-lines, for example, to show the selection range.
get_command(ga, s)¶

Return the command part of a minibuffer contents s.

get_label(ga)¶

Return the label, not including the prompt.

get_minibuffer_command_name(ga)¶

Return the command name in the minibuffer.

is_command(ga, s)¶

Return False if something, even a blank, follows a command.

reset_tab_cycling(ga)¶

Reset all tab cycling ivars.

set_label(ga, s)¶

Set the label after the prompt to s. The prompt never changes.

should_end(ga, char, stroke)¶

Return True if ga.get_arg should return.

show_tab_list(ga, tabList)¶

Show the tab list in the log tab.

trace_state(ga, char, completion, handler, state, stroke)¶

Trace the vars and ivars.

class leo.core.leoKeys.KeyHandlerClass(c)¶

A class to support emacs-style commands.

bindKey(pane, shortcut, callback, commandName, modeFlag=False, tag=None)¶

Bind the indicated shortcut (a Tk keystroke) to the callback.

No actual gui bindings are made: only entries in k.masterBindingsDict.

tag gives the source of the binding.

New in 4.4b3: make an actual binding in all the standard places.

The event will go to k.masterKeyHandler as always, so nothing really changes. except that k.masterKeyHandler will know the proper stroke.

createMenusFromConfigList(aList)¶

Create menus from aList instead of ‘hard coded’ menus. The ‘top’ menu has already been created.

createMenusFromTables()¶
createNewMenu(menuName, parentName='top', before=None)¶
createOpenWithMenu(parent, label, index, amp_index)¶
createOpenWithMenuFromTable(table)¶

table is a lists of dicts:

  • d.get(‘command’): one of “os.startfile”, “os.spawnl”, “os.spawnv” or “exec”.
  • d.get(‘shortcut’): the stroke (??)
  • d.get(‘name’): the menu label.

Leo executes command(arg+path) where path is the full path to the temp file. If ext is not None, the temp file has the given extension. Otherwise, Leo computes an extension based on the @language directive in effect.

createOpenWithMenuItemsFromTable(menu, table)¶

Create an entry in the Open with Menu from the table.

Each entry should be a sequence with 2 or 3 elements.

createNodeHierarchy(heads, forcecreate=False)¶

Create the proper hierarchy of nodes with headlines defined in ‘heads’ as children of the current position

params: heads - list of headlines in order to create, i.e. [‘foo’,’bar’,’baz’]

will create:
self -foo –bar —baz
forcecreate - If False (default), will not create nodes unless they don’t exist
If True, will create nodes regardless of existing nodes

returns the final position (‘baz’ in the above example)

nosentinels¶

position property returning the body text without sentinels

nthChild(n)¶
numberOfChildren()¶
parent()¶
parents()¶

Yield all parent positions of p.

parents_iter()¶

Yield all parent positions of p.

positionAfterDeletedTree()¶

Return the position corresponding to p.nodeAfterTree() after this node is deleted. This will be p.nodeAfterTree() unless p.next() exists.

This method allows scripts to traverse an outline, deleting nodes during the traversal. The pattern is:

p = c.rootPosition()
while p:
if <delete p?>:
    next = p.positionAfterDeletedTree()
    p.doDelete()
    p = next
else:
    p.moveToThreadNext()

This method also allows scripts to move nodes during a traversal, provided that nodes are moved to a “safe” spot so that moving a node does not change the position of any other nodes.

For example, the move-marked-nodes command first creates a move node, called ‘Clones of marked nodes’. All moved nodes become children of this move node. Inserting these nodes as children of the “move node” does not change the positions of other nodes. Deleting these nodes may change the position of nodes, but the pattern above handles this complication cleanly.

restoreCursorAndScroll()¶
saveCursorAndScroll()¶
script¶

position property returning the script formed by p and its descendants

scriptSetBodyString(s)¶

leo.core.leoPersistence module¶

Support for persistent clones, gnx’s and uA’s using @persistence trees.

class leo.core.leoPersistence.ConvertController(c, p)¶

A class to convert @file trees to @auto trees.

delete_at_data_nodes(root)¶

Delete all @data nodes pertaining to root.

import_from_string(s)¶

Import from s into a temp outline.

run()¶

Convert an @file tree to @auto tree.

set_expected_imported_headlines(root)¶

Set v._imported_headline for every vnode.

strip_sentinels()¶

Write the file to a string without headlines or sentinels.

class leo.core.leoPersistence.PersistenceDataController(c)¶

A class to handle persistence in foreign files, files created by @auto, @org-mode or @vim-outline node.

All required data are held in nodes having the following structure:

- @persistence
  - @data <headline of foreign node>
    - @gnxs
       body text: pairs of lines: gnx:<gnx><newline>unl:<unl>
    - @uas
        @ua <gnx>
            body text: the pickled uA
at_data_body(p)¶

Return the body text for p’s @data node.

clean()¶

Remove all @data nodes that do not correspond to an existing foreign file.

convert_at_file_to_at_auto(root)¶
create_outer_gnx_dict(root)¶

Return a dict whose keys are gnx’s and whose values are positions outside of root’s tree.

create_uas(at_uas, root)¶

Recreate uA’s from the @ua nodes in the @uas tree.

delete_at_data_children(at_data, root)¶

Delete all children of the @data node

drop_unl_parent(unl)¶

Drop the penultimate part of the unl.

drop_unl_tail(unl)¶

Drop the last part of the unl.

expected_headline(p)¶

Return the expected imported headline for p.

find_at_data_node(root)¶

Return the @data node for root, a foreign node. Create the node if it does not exist.

find_at_gnxs_node(root)¶

Find the @gnxs node for root, a foreign node. Create the @gnxs node if it does not exist.

find_at_persistence_node()¶

Find the first @persistence node in the outline. If it does not exist, create it as the last top-level node, so that no existing positions become invalid.

find_at_uas_node(root)¶

Find the @uas node for root, a foreign node. Create the @uas node if it does not exist.

find_best_match(root, unl_list)¶

Find the best partial matches of the tail in root’s tree.

find_exact_match(root, unl_list)¶

Find an exact match of the unl_list in root’s tree. The root does not appear in the unl_list.

find_position_for_relative_unl(root, unl)¶

Given a unl relative to root, return the node whose unl matches the longest suffix of the given unl.

find_representative_node(root, target)¶

root is a foreign node. target is a gnxs node within root’s tree.

Return a node outside of root’s tree that is cloned to target, preferring nodes outside any @<file> tree. Never return any node in any @persistence tree.

foreign_file_name(p)¶

Return the file name for p, a foreign file node.

has_at_data_node(root)¶

Return the @data node corresponding to root, a foreign node. Return None if no such node exists.

has_at_gnxs_node(root)¶

Find the @gnxs node for an @data node with the given unl. Return None if it does not exist.

Return the @persistence node or None if it does not exist.

Return True if p is an @file node.

Regularize node p so that it will not cause problems.

relative_unl(p, root)¶

Return the unl of p relative to the root position.

restore_gnx(d, gnx, root, unl)¶

d is an outer gnx dict, associating nodes outside the tree with positions. Let p1 be the position of the node within root’s tree corresponding to unl. Let p2 be the position of any node outside root’s tree with the given gnx. - Set p1.v.fileIndex = gnx. - If p2 exists, relink p1 so it is a clone of p2.

restore_gnxs(at_gnxs, root)¶

Recreate gnx’s and clone links from an @gnxs node. @gnxs nodes contain pairs of lines:

gnx:<gnx> unl:<unl>
unl(p)¶

Return the unl corresponding to the given position.

unl_tail(unl)¶

Return the last part of a unl.

Unhexlify and unpickle string s into p.

update_after_read_foreign_file(root)¶

Restore gnx’s, uAs and clone links using @gnxs nodes and @uas trees.

update_before_write_foreign_file(root)¶

Update the @data node for root, a foreign node. Create @gnxs nodes and @uas trees as needed.

leo.core.leoPlugins module¶

define the LeoPluginsController class.

class leo.core.leoPlugins.BaseLeoPlugin(tag, keywords)¶

Bases: object

A Convenience class to simplify plugin authoring

  • import the base class:

    from leoPlugins import leo.core.leoBasePlugin as leoBasePlugin

  • create a class which inherits from leoBasePlugin:

    class myPlugin(leoBasePlugin):

  • in the __init__ method of the class, call the parent constructor:

    def __init__(self, tag, keywords):
    leoBasePlugin.__init__(self, tag, keywords)

  • put the actual plugin code into a method; for this example, the work is done by myPlugin.handler()

  • put the class in a file which lives in the <LeoDir>/plugins directory

    for this example it is named myPlugin.py

  • add code to register the plugin:

    leoPlugins.registerHandler("after-create-leo-frame", Hello)

BaseLeoPlugins has 3 methods for setting commands

  • setCommand:

    def setCommand(self, commandName, handler, 
        shortcut = None, pane = 'all', verbose = True):

  • setMenuItem:

    def setMenuItem(self, menu, commandName = None, handler = None):

  • setButton:

    def setButton(self, buttonText = None, commandName = None, color = None):

variables

CommandName:the string typed into minibuffer to execute the handler
Handler:the method in the class which actually does the work
Shortcut:the key combination to activate the command
Menu:a string designating on of the menus (‘File’, Edit’, ‘Outline’, ...)
ButtonText:the text to put on the button if one is being created.

Contents of file <LeoDir>/plugins/hello.py:

class Hello(BaseLeoPlugin):
    def __init__(self, tag, keywords):

        # call parent __init__
        BaseLeoPlugin.__init__(self, tag, keywords)

        # if the plugin object defines only one command, 
        # just give it a name. You can then create a button and menu entry
        self.setCommand('Hello', self.hello)
        self.setButton()
        self.setMenuItem('Cmds')

        # create a command with a shortcut
        self.setCommand('Hola', self.hola, 'Alt-Ctrl-H')

        # create a button using different text than commandName
        self.setButton('Hello in Spanish')

        # create a menu item with default text
        self.setMenuItem('Cmds')

        # define a command using setMenuItem 
        self.setMenuItem('Cmds', 'Ciao baby', self.ciao)

    def hello(self, event):
        g.pr("hello from node %s" % self.c.p.h)

    def hola(self, event):
        g.pr("hola from node %s" % self.c.p.h)

    def ciao(self, event):
        g.pr("ciao baby (%s)" % self.c.p.h)


leoPlugins.registerHandler("after-create-leo-frame", Hello)
setButton(buttonText=None, commandName=None, color=None)¶

Associate an existing command with a ‘button’

setCommand(commandName, handler, shortcut=None, pane='all', verbose=True)¶

Associate a command name with handler code, optionally defining a keystroke shortcut

setMenuItem(menu, commandName=None, handler=None)¶

Create a menu item in ‘menu’ using text ‘commandName’ calling handler ‘handler’ if commandName and handler are none, use the most recently defined values

class leo.core.leoPlugins.CommandChainDispatcher(commands=None)¶

Dispatch calls to a chain of commands until some func can handle it

Usage: instantiate, execute “add” to add commands (with optional priority), execute normally via f() calling mechanism.

add(func, priority=0)¶

Add a func to the cmd chain with given priority

exception leo.core.leoPlugins.TryNext(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

Try next hook exception.

Raise this in your hook function to indicate that the next hook handler should be used to handle the operation. If you pass arguments to the constructor those arguments will be used by the next hook instead of the original ones.

leo.core.leoPlugins.init()¶

Init g.app.pluginsController.

leo.core.leoPlugins.registerHandler(tags, fn)¶

A wrapper so plugins can still call leoPlugins.registerHandler.

leo.core.leoPymacs module¶

A module to allow the Pymacs bridge to access Leo data.

All code in this module must be called from Emacs: calling Pymacs.lisp in other situations will hang Leo.

Notes:

  • The init method adds the parent directory of leoPymacs.py to Python’s sys.path. This is essential to make imports work from inside Emacs.

  • As of Leo 4.5, the following code, when executed from an Emacs buffer, will open trunk/leo/test.leo:

    (pymacs-load "c:\leo.repo\trunk\leo\core\leoPymacs" "leo-")
(setq c (leo-open "c:\leo.repo\trunk\leo\test\test.leo"))

    Note that full path names are required in each case.

leo.core.leoPymacs.dump(anObject)¶
leo.core.leoPymacs.get_app()¶

Scripts can use g.app.scriptDict for communication with pymacs.

leo.core.leoPymacs.get_g()¶
leo.core.leoPymacs.hello()¶
leo.core.leoPymacs.init()¶
leo.core.leoPymacs.open(fileName=None)¶
leo.core.leoPymacs.run_script(c, script, p=None)¶
leo.core.leoPymacs.script_result()¶

leo.core.leoQt module¶

A module to allow careful, uniform imports from PyQt4 or PyQt5. The isQt5 constant is True only if all important PyQt5 modules were imported. Optional modules may fail to load without affecting the isQt5 constant.

Callers are expected to use the PyQt5 spellings of modules: - Use QtWidgets, not QtGui, for all widget classes. - Use QtGui, not QtWidgets, for all other classes in the PyQt4 QtGui module. - Similarly, use QtWebKitWidgets rather than QtWebKit.

leo.core.leoRope module¶

leo.core.leoRst module¶

Support for restructured text (rST), adapted from rst3 plugin.

For full documentation, see: http://leoeditor.com/rstplugin3.html

To generate documents from rST files, Python’s docutils_ module must be installed. The code will use the SilverCity_ syntax coloring package if is is available.

class leo.core.leoRst.AnchorHtmlParserClass(rst, p)¶

Bases: leo.core.leoRst.LinkAnchorParserClass

This htmlparser does the first step of relocating: finding all the anchors within the html nodes.

Each anchor is mapped to a tuple:
(current_file, position).

Filters out markers which mark the beginning of the html code for a node.

handle_starttag(tag, attrs)¶

  1. Find out if the current tag is an achor.

  2. If the current tag is an anchor, update the mapping;

    anchor -> (filename, p)

class leo.core.leoRst.HtmlParserClass(rst)¶

Bases: leo.core.leoRst.LinkAnchorParserClass

The responsibility of the html parser is:
  1. Find out which html code belongs to which node.
  2. Keep a stack of open tags which apply to the current node.
  3. Keep a list of tags which should be included in the nodes, even though they might be closed. The <style> tag is one example of that.

Later, we have to relocate inter-file links: if a reference to another location is in a file, we must change the link.

feed(line)¶
handle_endtag(tag)¶
  1. Set the second element of the current top of stack.
  2. If this is the end tag for an anchor for a node, store the current stack for that node.
handle_starttag(tag, attrs)¶
  1. Find out if the current tag is an achor.
  2. If it is an anchor, we check if this anchor marks the beginning of a new node
  3. If a new node begins, then we might have to store html code for the previous node.
  4. In any case, put the new tag on the stack.
class leo.core.leoRst.LinkAnchorParserClass(rst)¶

Bases: HTMLParser.HTMLParser

A class to recognize anchors and links in HTML documents. A special marker is the “node_marker” which demarkates the border between node and the next.

is_anchor(tag, attrs)¶

Check if the current tag is an anchor. Returns all anchors. Works with docutils 0.4

is_link(tag, attrs)¶

Return True if tag, attrs is represents a link.

is_node_marker(attrs)¶

Return the name of the anchor, if this is an anchor for the beginning of a node, False otherwise.

class leo.core.leoRst.LinkHtmlparserClass(rst, p)¶

Bases: leo.core.leoRst.LinkAnchorParserClass

This html parser does the second step of relocating links: 1. It scans the html code for links. 2. If there is a link which links to a previously processed file

then this link is changed so that it now refers to the node.
get_replacements()¶
handle_starttag(tag, attrs)¶

  1. Find out if the current tag is an achor.

  2. If the current tag is an anchor, update the mapping;

    anchor -> p

    Update the list of replacements for the document.

getPublicCommands()¶

Add the names of commands defined in this file to c.commandsDict

handleCodeMode(lines)¶

Handle the preprocessed body text in code mode as follows:

  • Blank lines are copied after being cleaned.
  • @ @rst-markup lines get copied as is.
  • Everything else gets put into a code-block directive.
handleDocOnlyMode(p, lines)¶

Handle the preprocessed body text in doc_only mode as follows:

  • Blank lines are copied after being cleaned.
  • @ @rst-markup lines get copied as is.
  • All doc parts get copied.
  • All code parts are ignored.

Such entries may arise from @rst-option or @rst-options in the headline, or from @ @rst-options doc parts.

Return the underlining string to be used at the given level for string s. This includes the headline, and possibly a leading overlining line.

write(s, theFile=None)¶
writeAtAutoFile(p, fileName, outputFile, trialWrite=False)¶

Write an @auto tree containing imported rST code. The caller will close the output file.

writeBody(p)¶
writeHeadline(p)¶

Generate an rST section if options permit it. Remove headline commands from the headline first, and never generate an rST section for @rst-option and @rst-options.

writeHeadlineHelper(p)¶
writeNode(p)¶

Format a node according to the options presently in effect.

writeNodeToString(p=None, ext=None)¶

Scan p’s tree (defaults to presently selected tree) looking for @rst nodes. Convert the first node found to an ouput of the type specified by ext.

The @rst may or may not be followed by a filename; the filename is ignored, and its type does not affect ext or the output generated in any way.

ext should start with a period: .html, .tex or None (specifies rst output).

Returns (p, s), where p is the position of the @rst node and s is the converted text.

writePreformat(p)¶

Write p’s body text lines as if preformatted.

line 1
line 2 etc.
writeSlideTitle(title, n, n_tot)¶

leo.core.leoShadow module¶

leoShadow.py

This code allows users to use Leo with files which contain no sentinels and still have information flow in both directions between outlines and derived files.

Private files contain sentinels: they live in the Leo-shadow subdirectory. Public files contain no sentinels: they live in the parent (main) directory.

When Leo first reads an @shadow we create a file without sentinels in the regular directory.

The slightly hard thing to do is to pick up changes from the file without sentinels, and put them into the file with sentinels.

Settings: - @string shadow_subdir (default: .leo_shadow): name of the shadow directory.

  • @string shadow_prefix (default: x): prefix of shadow files. This prefix allows the shadow file and the original file to have different names. This is useful for name-based tools like py.test.
class leo.core.leoShadow.ShadowController(c, trace=False, trace_writers=False)¶

A class to manage @shadow files

class AtShadowTestCase(c, p, shadowController, lax, trace=False)¶

Bases: unittest.case.TestCase

Support @shadow-test nodes.

These nodes should have two descendant nodes: ‘before’ and ‘after’.

class ShadowController.Sourcereader(shadowController, lines)¶

A class to read lines sequentially.

The class keeps an internal index, so that each call to get returns the next line.

Index returns the internal index, and sync advances the index to the the desired line.

The index is the next line to be returned.

The line numbering starts from 0.

atEnd()¶
dump(title)¶
get()¶

Return the next line.

index()¶
size()¶
sync(i)¶
class ShadowController.Sourcewriter(shadowController)¶

Convenience class to capture output to a file.

Similar to class Sourcereader.

ShadowController.baseDirName()¶
ShadowController.check_the_final_output(new_private_lines, new_public_lines, sentinel_lines, marker)¶

Check that we produced a valid output.

Input:
new_targetlines: the lines with sentinels which produce changed_lines_without_sentinels. sentinels: new_targetlines should include all the lines from sentinels.
checks:
  1. new_targetlines without sentinels must equal changed_lines_without_sentinels.
  2. the sentinel lines of new_targetlines must match ‘sentinels’

ShadowController.message(s)¶
ShadowController.pathName(filename)¶

Return the full path name of filename.

ShadowController.propagate_changed_lines(new_public_lines, old_private_lines, marker, p=None)¶

Propagate changes from ‘new_public_lines’ to ‘old_private_lines.

We compare the old and new public lines, create diffs and propagate the diffs to the new private lines, copying sentinels as well.

We have two invariants: 1. We never delete any sentinels.

New at 2010/01/07: Replacements preserve sentinel locations.
  1. Insertions that happen at the boundary between nodes will be put at the end of a node. However, insertions must always be done within sentinels.
ShadowController.propagate_changes(old_public_file, old_private_file)¶

Propagate the changes from the public file (without_sentinels) to the private file (with_sentinels)

ShadowController.push_filter_mapping(lines, marker)¶

Given the lines of a file, filter out all Leo sentinels, and return a mapping:

stripped file -> original file

Filtering should be the same as separate_sentinels

ShadowController.replaceFileWithString(fn, s)¶

Replace the file with s if s is different from theFile’s contents.

Return True if theFile was changed.

Returns (regular_lines, sentinel_lines)

ShadowController.strip_sentinels_with_map(lines, marker)¶

Strip sentinels from lines, a list of lines with sentinels.

Return (results,mapping)

‘lines’: A list of lines containing sentinels. ‘results’: The list of non-sentinel lines. ‘mapping’: A list mapping each line in results to the original list.

results[i] comes from line mapping[i] of the original lines.

BaseTangleCommands.scan_derived_file(s)¶
BaseTangleCommands.scan_short_val(s, i)¶
BaseTangleCommands.section_check(name)¶
BaseTangleCommands.select_next_sentinel(part_start_flag=True)¶

The next sentinel will be either (a) a section part reference, using the “before” comment style for that part - when there are section references yet to interpolate for this part - when we’re followed by another part for this section (b) an end sentinel using the “after” comment style for the current part - when we’ve exhausted the parts for this section or (c) end of file for the root section The above requires that the parts in the tst be aware of the section interpolations each part will make

BaseTangleCommands.setRootFromHeadline(p)¶
BaseTangleCommands.setRootFromText(s, report_errors=True)¶
BaseTangleCommands.skip_body(p, delims)¶

The following subsections contain the interface between the Tangle and Untangle commands. This interface is an important hack, and allows Untangle to avoid duplicating the logic in skip_tree and its allies.

The aha is this: just at the time the Tangle command enters a definition into the symbol table, all the information is present that Untangle needs to update that definition.

To get whitespace exactly right we retain the outline’s leading whitespace and remove leading whitespace from the updated definition.

BaseTangleCommands.skip_code(s, i, delims)¶
BaseTangleCommands.skip_doc(s, i, delims)¶
BaseTangleCommands.skip_headline(p)¶
BaseTangleCommands.skip_section_name(s, i)¶

Checks the given symbol table for defined but never referenced sections.

BaseTangleCommands.token_type(s, i, report_errors=True)¶

This method returns a code indicating the apparent kind of token at the position i.

The caller must determine whether section definiton tokens are valid.

returns (kind, end) and sets global root_name using setRootFromText(). end is only valid for kind in (section_ref, section_def, at_root).

BaseTangleCommands.update_def(name, part_number, head, code, tail, is_root_flag=False)¶
BaseTangleCommands.ust_dump()¶
BaseTangleCommands.ust_enter(name, part, of, code, nl_flag, is_root_flag=False)¶

This routine enters names and their code parts into the given table. The ‘part’ and ‘of’ parameters are taken from the “(part n of m)” portion of the line that introduces the section definition in the C code.

If no part numbers are given the caller should set the ‘part’ and ‘of’ parameters to zero. The caller is reponsible for checking for duplicate parts.

This function handles names scanned from a source file; the corresponding st_enter routine handles names scanned from outlines.

BaseTangleCommands.ust_lookup(name, part_number, is_root_flag=False, update_flag=False)¶

Search the given table for a part matching the name and part number.

BaseTangleCommands.ust_warn_about_orphans()¶

Issues a warning about any sections in the derived file for which no corresponding section has been seen in the outline.

BaseTangleCommands.warning(s)¶

runLeoTest(path, verbose=False, full=False)¶
runProfileOnNode(p, outputPath=None)¶
runRootFileTangleTest(p)¶

Code for testing tangle of @root. The first child is the top node of the outline to be processed; the remaining siblings have headlines corresponding to the file names that should be generated, with the bodies containing the intended contents of the corresponding file.

runRootFileUntangleTest(p)¶

Code for testing untangle into @root. The first child is the top node of the outline to be processed; it gets copied to a sibling that gets modified by the untangle. The (pre-first child copy) second child represents the resulting tree which should result from the untangle. The remaining siblings have headlines corresponding to the file names that should be untangled, with the bodies containing the intended contents of the corresponding file. As a final check, the result of the untangle gets tangled, and the result gets compared to the (pseudo) files.

runTestsExternally(all, marked)¶

Run any kind of external unit test.

leo.core.leoTest.factorial(n)¶

Return the factorial of n, an exact integer >= 0.

If the result is small enough to fit in an int, return an int. Else return a long.

>>> [factorial(n) for n in range(6)]
[1, 1, 2, 6, 24, 120]
>>> factorial(30)
265252859812191058636308480000000
>>> factorial(-1)
Traceback (most recent call last):
    ...
ValueError: n must be >= 0

Factorials of floats are OK, but the float must be an exact integer: >>> factorial(30.1) Traceback (most recent call last):

...

ValueError: n must be exact integer >>> factorial(30.0) 265252859812191058636308480000000

It must also not be ridiculously large: >>> factorial(1e100) Traceback (most recent call last):

...

OverflowError: n too large

putIvarsToVnode(p)¶
recognizeStartOfTypingWord(old_lines, old_row, old_col, old_ch, new_lines, new_row, new_col, new_ch, prev_row, prev_col)¶

A potentially user-modifiable method that should return True if the typing indicated by the params starts a new ‘word’ for the purposes of undo with ‘word’ granularity.

u.setUndoTypingParams calls this method only when the typing could possibly continue a previous word. In other words, undo will work safely regardless of the value returned here.

old_ch is the char at the given (Tk) row, col of old_lines. new_ch is the char at the given (Tk) row, col of new_lines.

The present code uses only old_ch and new_ch. The other arguments are given for use by more sophisticated algorithms.

redo(event=None)¶

Redo the operation undone by the last undo.

redoClearRecentFiles()¶
redoCloneMarkedNodes()¶
redoCloneNode()¶
redoDehoistNode()¶
redoDeleteMarkedNodes()¶
redoDeleteNode()¶
redoDemote()¶
redoGroup()¶

Process beads until the matching ‘afterGroup’ bead is seen.

redoHelper()¶
redoHoistNode()¶
redoInsertNode()¶
redoMark()¶
redoMenuName(name)¶
redoMove()¶
redoMoveMarkedNodes()¶
redoNodeContents()¶
redoPromote()¶
redoSort()¶
redoTree()¶

Redo replacement of an entire tree.

redoTyping()¶
restoreTnodeUndoInfo(bunch)¶
restoreTree(treeInfo)¶

Use the tree info to restore all VNode data, including all links.

restoreVnodeUndoInfo(bunch)¶

Restore all ivars saved in the bunch.

saveTree(p, treeInfo=None)¶

Return a list of tuples with all info needed to handle a general undo operation.

setIvarsFromBunch(bunch)¶
setIvarsFromVnode(p)¶
setRedoType(theType)¶
setUndoType(theType)¶
setUndoTypes()¶
setUndoTypingParams(p, undo_type, oldText, newText, oldSel, newSel, oldYview=None)¶

Save enough information so a typing operation can be undone and redone.

Do nothing when called from the undo/redo logic because the Undo and Redo commands merely reset the bead pointer.

trace()¶
undo(event=None)¶

Undo the operation described by the undo parameters.

undoClearRecentFiles()¶
undoCloneMarkedNodes()¶
undoCloneNode()¶
undoDehoistNode()¶
undoDeleteMarkedNodes()¶
undoDeleteNode()¶
undoDemote()¶
undoGroup()¶

Process beads until the matching ‘beforeGroup’ bead is seen.

undoHelper()¶
undoHoistNode()¶
undoInsertNode()¶
undoMark()¶
undoMenuName(name)¶
undoMove()¶
undoMoveMarkedNodes()¶
undoNodeContents()¶

Undo all changes to the contents of a node, including headline and body text, and marked bits.

undoPromote()¶
undoRedoText(p, leading, trailing, oldMidLines, newMidLines, oldNewlines, newNewlines, tag='undo', undoType=None)¶

Handle text undo and redo: converts _new_ text into _old_ text.

undoRedoTree(p, new_data, old_data)¶

Replace p and its subtree using old_data during undo.

undoSort()¶
undoTree()¶

Redo replacement of an entire tree.

undoTyping()¶
updateMarks(oldOrNew)¶

Update dirty and marked bits.

leo.core.leoVersion module¶

A module holding version-related info.

leo.core.leoVim module¶

Leo’s vim emulator.

class leo.core.leoVim.VimCommands(vc, c)¶

A class that handles vim simulation in Leo.

class LoadFileAtCursor(vc)¶

A class to handle Vim’s :r command. This class supports the do_tab callback.

load_file_at_cursor(fn)¶
tab_callback()¶

Called when the user types :r<tab>

class VimCommands.Substitution(vc, all_lines)¶

A class to handle Vim’s :% command.

class VimCommands.Tabnew(vc)¶

A class to handle Vim’s :tabnew command. This class supports the do_tab callback.

open_file_by_name(fn)¶
tab_callback()¶

Called when the user types :tabnew<tab>

VimCommands.accept(vc, add_to_dot=True, handler=None)¶

Accept the present stroke. Optionally, this can set the dot or change vc.handler. This can be a no-op, but even then it is recommended.

VimCommands.add_to_dot(vc, stroke=None)¶

Add a new VimEvent to vc.command_list. Never change vc.command_list if vc.in_dot is True Never add . to vc.command_list

VimCommands.begin_insert_mode(vc, i=None, w=None)¶

Common code for beginning insert mode.

VimCommands.begin_motion(vc, motion_func)¶

Start an inner motion.

VimCommands.compute_dot(vc, stroke)¶

Compute the dot and set vc.dot.

VimCommands.create_arrow_d(vc)¶

Return a dict binding all arrows to vc.arrow.

VimCommands.create_dispatch_dicts(vc)¶

Create all dispatch dicts.

VimCommands.create_motion_dispatch_d(vc)¶

Return the dispatch dict for motions. Keys are strokes, values are methods.

VimCommands.create_normal_dispatch_d(vc)¶

Return the dispatch dict for normal mode. Keys are strokes, values are methods.

VimCommands.create_vis_dispatch_d(vc)¶

Create a dispatch dict for visual mode. Keys are strokes, values are methods.

VimCommands.cycle_all_focus(vc, event=None)¶

Cycle all focus

VimCommands.cycle_focus(vc, event=None)¶

Cycle focus

VimCommands.delegate(vc)¶

Delegate the present key to k.masterKeyHandler.

VimCommands.do(vc, o, event=None)¶

Do one or more Leo commands by name.

VimCommands.do_inner_motion(vc, restart=False)¶

Handle strokes in motions.

VimCommands.do_insert_mode(vc)¶

Handle insert mode: delegate all strokes to k.masterKeyHandler.

VimCommands.do_key(vc, event)¶

Handle the next key in vim mode: - Set vc.event, vc.w, vc.stroke and vc.ch for all handlers. - Call vc.handler. Return True if k.masterKeyHandler should handle this key.

VimCommands.do_normal_mode(vc)¶

Handle strokes in normal mode.

VimCommands.do_state(vc, d, mode_name)¶

General dispatcher code. d is a dispatch dict.

VimCommands.do_visual_mode(vc)¶

Handle strokes in visual mode.

VimCommands.done(vc, add_to_dot=True, return_value=True, set_dot=True, stroke=None)¶

Complete a command, preserving text and optionally updating the dot.

VimCommands.end_insert_mode(vc)¶

End an insert mode started with the a,A,i,o and O commands.

VimCommands.finishCreate(vc)¶

Complete the initialization for the VimCommands class.

VimCommands.getPublicCommands(vc)¶

Add the names of commands defined in this file to c.commandsDict

VimCommands.handle_specials(vc)¶

Return True vc.stroke is an Escape or a Return in the outline pane.

VimCommands.ignore(vc)¶

Ignore the present key without passing it to k.masterKeyHandler.

Important: all code now calls vc.quit() after vc.ignore. This code could do that, but the calling v.quit() emphasizes what happens.

VimCommands.in_headline(vc, w)¶

Return True if we are in a headline edit widget.

VimCommands.in_tree(vc, w)¶

Return True if we are in the outline pane, but not in a headline.

VimCommands.init_constant_ivars(vc)¶

Init ivars whose values never change.

VimCommands.init_dot_ivars(vc)¶

Init all dot-related ivars.

VimCommands.init_persistent_ivars(vc)¶

Init ivars that are never re-inited.

VimCommands.init_scanner_vars(vc, event)¶

Init all ivars used by the scanner.

VimCommands.init_state_ivars(vc)¶

Init all ivars related to command state.

VimCommands.is_body(vc, w)¶

Return True if w is the QTextBrowser of the body pane.

VimCommands.is_head(vc, w)¶

Return True if w is an headline edit widget.

VimCommands.is_plain_key(vc, stroke)¶

Return True if stroke is a plain key.

VimCommands.is_text_wrapper(vc, w=None)¶

Return True if w is a text widget.

VimCommands.not_ready(vc)¶

Print a not ready message and quit.

VimCommands.on_idle(vc, tag, keys)¶

The idle-time handler for the VimCommands class.

VimCommands.on_same_line(vc, s, i1, i2)¶

Return True if i1 and i2 are on the same line.

VimCommands.oops(vc, message)¶

Report an internal error

VimCommands.print_dot(vc, event=None)¶

Print the dot.

VimCommands.q_command(vc, event=None)¶

Quit the present Leo outline, prompting for saves.

VimCommands.qa_command(vc, event=None)¶

Quit only if there are no unsaved changes.

VimCommands.quit(vc)¶

Abort any present command. Don’t set the dot and enter normal mode.

VimCommands.quit_now(vc, event=None)¶

Quit immediately.

VimCommands.reset(vc, setFocus)¶

Called from k.keyboardQuit when the user types Ctrl-G (setFocus = True). Also called when the user clicks the mouse (setFocus = False).

VimCommands.revert(vc, event=None)¶

Revert all changes to a .leo file, prompting if there have been changes.

VimCommands.save_body(vc)¶

Undoably preserve any changes to body text.

VimCommands.set_border(vc, kind=None, w=None, activeFlag=None)¶

Set the border color of vc.w, depending on state. Called from qtBody.onFocusColorHelper and vc.show_status.

VimCommands.set_property(vc, w, focus_flag)¶

Set the property of w, depending on focus and state.

VimCommands.shell_command(vc, event=None)¶

Execute a shell command.

VimCommands.show_command(vc)¶

Show the accumulating command.

VimCommands.show_dot(vc)¶

Show the dot.

VimCommands.show_status(vc)¶

Show vc.state and vc.command_list

VimCommands.test_for_insert_escape(vc, w)¶

Return True if the j,j escape sequence has ended insert mode.

VimCommands.to_bol(vc, s, i)¶

Return the index of the first character on the line containing s[i]

VimCommands.to_eol(vc, s, i)¶

Return the index of the last character on the line containing s[i]

VimCommands.toggle_vim_mode(vc, event=None)¶

toggle vim-mode.

VimCommands.toggle_vim_trace(vc, event=None)¶

toggle vim tracing.

VimCommands.toggle_vim_trainer_mode(vc, event=None)¶

toggle vim-trainer mode.

VimCommands.update_dot_before_search(vc, find_pattern, change_pattern)¶

A callback that updates the dot just before searching. At present, this leaves the dot unchanged. Use the n or N commands to repeat searches,

VimCommands.update_selection_after_search(vc)¶

Extend visual mode’s selection after a search. Called from leoFind.showSuccess.

VimCommands.vim_0(vc)¶

Handle zero, either the ‘0’ command or part of a repeat count.

VimCommands.vim_A(vc)¶

Append text at the end the line N times.

VimCommands.vim_F(vc)¶

Back to the Nth occurrence of <char>.

VimCommands.vim_F2(vc)¶

Handle F <stroke>

VimCommands.vim_G(vc)¶

Put the cursor on the last character of the file.

VimCommands.vim_N(vc)¶

Repeat last search N times (reversed).

VimCommands.vim_O(vc)¶

Open a new line above the current line N times.

VimCommands.vim_P(vc)¶

Paste text at the cursor or paste a node before the present node.

VimCommands.vim_T(vc)¶

Back before the Nth occurrence of <char>.

VimCommands.vim_T2(vc)¶

Handle T <stroke>

VimCommands.vim_V(vc)¶

Visually select line.

VimCommands.vim_Y(vc)¶

Yank a Leo outline.

VimCommands.vim_a(vc)¶

Append text after the cursor N times.

VimCommands.vim_arrow(vc)¶

Handle all non-Alt arrows in any mode. This method attempts to leave focus unchanged.

VimCommands.vim_b(vc)¶

N words backward.

VimCommands.vim_c(vc)¶

N cc change N lines N c{motion} change the text that is moved over with {motion} VIS c change the highlighted text

VimCommands.vim_c2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_caret(vc)¶

Move to start of line.

VimCommands.vim_colon(vc)¶

Enter the minibuffer.

VimCommands.vim_comma(vc)¶

Handle a comma in normal mode.

VimCommands.vim_comma2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_ctrl_r(vc)¶

Redo the last command.

VimCommands.vim_d(vc)¶

N dd delete N lines d{motion} delete the text that is moved over with {motion}

VimCommands.vim_d2(vc)¶

Handle the second stroke of the d command.

VimCommands.vim_d3(vc)¶

Complete the d command after the cursor has moved.

VimCommands.vim_di(vc)¶

Handle delete inner commands.

VimCommands.vim_digits(vc)¶

Handle a digit that starts an outer repeat count.

VimCommands.vim_digits_2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_dollar(vc)¶

Move the cursor to the end of the line.

VimCommands.vim_dot(vc)¶

Repeat the last command.

VimCommands.vim_e(vc)¶

Forward to the end of the Nth word.

VimCommands.vim_esc(vc)¶

Handle Esc while accumulating a normal mode command.

Esc terminates the a,A,i,o and O commands normally. Call vc.end_insert command to support repeat counts such as 5a<lots of typing><esc>

VimCommands.vim_f(vc)¶

move past the Nth occurrence of <stroke>.

VimCommands.vim_f2(vc)¶

Handle f <stroke>

VimCommands.vim_g(vc)¶

N ge backward to the end of the Nth word N gg goto line N (default: first line), on the first non-blank character

gv start highlighting on previous visual area
VimCommands.vim_g2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_h(vc)¶

Move the cursor left n chars, but not out of the present line.

VimCommands.vim_i(vc)¶

Insert text before the cursor N times.

VimCommands.vim_j(vc)¶

N j Down n lines.

VimCommands.vim_k(vc)¶

Cursor up N lines.

VimCommands.vim_l(vc)¶

Move the cursor right vc.n chars, but not out of the present line.

VimCommands.vim_m(vc)¶

m<a-zA-Z> mark current position with mark.

VimCommands.vim_m2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_n(vc)¶

Repeat last search N times.

VimCommands.vim_o(vc)¶

Open a new line below the current line N times.

VimCommands.vim_p(vc)¶

Paste after the cursor.

VimCommands.vim_pound(vc)¶

Find previous occurance of word under the cursor.

VimCommands.vim_q(vc)¶

q stop recording q<A-Z> record typed characters, appended to register <a-z> q<a-z> record typed characters into register <a-z>

VimCommands.vim_q2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_question(vc)¶

Begin a search.

VimCommands.vim_r(vc)¶

Replace next N characters with <char>

VimCommands.vim_r2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_redo(vc)¶

N Ctrl-R redo last N changes

VimCommands.vim_return(vc)¶

Handle a return key, regardless of mode. In the body pane only, it has special meaning.

VimCommands.vim_s(vc)¶

Change N characters

VimCommands.vim_s2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_slash(vc)¶

Begin a search.

VimCommands.vim_star(vc)¶

Find previous occurance of word under the cursor.

VimCommands.vim_t(vc)¶

Move before the Nth occurrence of <char> to the right.

VimCommands.vim_t2(vc)¶

Handle t <stroke>

VimCommands.vim_u(vc)¶

U undo the last command.

VimCommands.vim_v(vc)¶

Start visual mode.

VimCommands.vim_w(vc)¶

N words forward.

VimCommands.vim_x(vc)¶

Works like Del if there is a character after the cursor. Works like Backspace otherwise.

VimCommands.vim_y(vc)¶

N yy yank N lines N y{motion} yank the text moved over with {motion}

VimCommands.vim_y2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vim_y3(vc)¶

Complete the y command after the cursor has moved.

VimCommands.vim_z(vc)¶

zb redraw current line at bottom of window zz redraw current line at center of window zt redraw current line at top of window

VimCommands.vim_z2(vc)¶
VimCommands.vis_J(vc)¶

Join the highlighted lines.

VimCommands.vis_c(vc)¶

Change the highlighted text.

VimCommands.vis_d(vc)¶

Delete the highlighted text and terminate visual mode.

VimCommands.vis_escape(vc)¶

Handle Escape in visual mode.

VimCommands.vis_u(vc)¶

Make highlighted text lowercase.

VimCommands.vis_v(vc)¶

End visual mode.

VimCommands.vis_y(vc)¶

Yank the highlighted text.

VimCommands.visual_line_helper(vc)¶

Extend the selection as necessary in visual line mode.

VimCommands.w_command(vc, event=None)¶

Save the .leo file.

VimCommands.widget_name(vc, w)¶
VimCommands.wq_command(vc, event=None)¶

Save all open files and exit.

VimCommands.xa_command(vc, event=None)¶

Save all open files and keep working.

A class to contain the components of the dot.

Return the best human-readable form of stroke.
